summary: real-time quantitative PCR can be a very powerful and accurate technique to examine gene transcription patterns in different biological conditions. real-time normalisation occurs against only one reference gene, usually GAPDH or ACTB, without validation of its expression stability. the goal of this study was to establish a reliable set of reference genes for studies concerning normal equine skin and equine sarcoids. housekeeping genes are most widely used as reference genes, based on the assumption that they are constitutively expressed in most tissues and under certain circumstances. however, it has been demonstrated that the expression levels of these genes may vary considerably in different tissues, different cell types and different disease stages, particularly in clinical samples associated with malignant disease. affected horses show genetic predisposition for the development of equine sarcoids. bovine papillomavirus plays an important role in the aetiology of equine sarcoids. a well suited internal control should first of all be established. the sequencing of UBB revealed 1 gap and 3 SNPs compared to the original sequence (98% identity) the gap is probably due to sequencing errors; the SNPs did not result in an amino acid variation. ACTB, B2M, GAPDH and TBP were found to be best endogenous control genes for real-time qPCR of lamella in the hoof of horses. ACTB and B2M were found to be the best endogenous control genes for real-time qPCR of lamella. in all 3 cases, the inclusion of a 4th gene had no significant contribution (low V3/4 value) to the NF. the described set of reference genes can be used in gene expression studies in normal skin, equine sarcoids and the combination of both. real-time PCR products were visualised by gelelectrophoresis. for every assay, a single amplicon with the expected size was generated without primer dimer formation. formation of primer dimers and unspecific amplification is a major point of attention. geNorm analysis The gene expression stability over the different samples was analysed using the geNorm software. the ranking of the 6 candidate reference genes according to their M value was not equivalent between the normal skin samples, the equine sarcoid samples and the combination of both types of samples. ACTB, TUBA1 and UBB proved to be the most stable genes. reference genes chosen to calculate normalisation factor are printed in bold. the more genes included, the more accurate the NF is. however, including too many genes may increase the risk of using unsuitable genes. if cut off is made too stringent, stably expressed reference genes may be excluded. a method for genomic DNA-free RNA extraction from normal skin and equine sarcoids was optimised. a reference gene assay for reliable normalisation of real-time qPCR data was designed. a method for genomic DNA-free RNA extraction from normal skin and equine sarcoids was designed. the samples were collected from the ventral abdomen, one from the throat region and one from the shoulder. RNA extraction and cDNA synthesis Total RNA was isolated from the samples using TRIR (ABgene) according to the manufacturer's instructions. a PCR was performed with primers for GAPDH to check for the presence of cDNA. the reaction conditions used in this PCR were identical to the minus RT control. the primers were designed by the Primer 3 software. technical information about the primers and amplicons are listed in Table 3.
